byline.contributor: Adam Nossiter reported from St.-Étienne-du-Rouvray, and Alissa J. Rubin and Benoît Morenne from Paris. Reporting was contributed by Daphné Anglès, Lilia Blaise and Martin de Bourmont from Paris; Hannah Olivennes from London; Rukmini Callimachi from Stuttgart, Germany; and Laurie Goodstein from New York.
byline.original: By ADAM NOSSITER, ALISSA J. RUBIN and BENOÎT MORENNE

abstract: Two men armed with knives enter Eglise St-Etienne, 17th-century church in town of St-Etienne-du-Rouvray in Normandy, France, killing Rev Jacques Hamel and taking several hostages before being shot dead by police; Islamic State claims responsibility for attack, fourth linked to extremist group in Western Europe in under two weeks, framing assault as act of religious war between Muslims and Christians.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande said that the Islamic State was behind the assault, the latest in a series that has left Europe stunned, fearful and angry.

headline.main: ISIS Says Its ‘Soldiers’ Attacked Church in France, Killing Priest
headline.print_headline: ISIS Says Its ‘Soldiers’ Killed Priest in Knifing at French Church

snippet: President François Hollande said that the Islamic State was behind the assault, the latest in a series that has left Europe stunned, fearful and angry....

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
